abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, with both performances by
            the Bank and Borrower rates as satisfactory. Regardless of
            success, some lessons from the experience of the project
            follows. The difficulty in ensuring full government
            ownership, particularly in post-conflict settings, combined
            with support from multiple donors should not be
            underestimated. Adequate time and resources during project
            preparation should be allocated to that effect, to achieve
            the appropriate project design. The project has confirmed
            the value of supporting sector-wide programs; it has helped
            the government put together an overall, sector strategy that
            could be jointly financed by donors and the government.
            Nonetheless, it is suggested that future operations, be
            given careful attention to the design of monitoring and
            evaluation systems, including the choice of appropriate
            indicators, the establishment of a baseline, the balance
            between routine data collection, and periodic surveys, and
            the inclusion of monitoring and evaluation specialists in
            the program management team. In addition, the Bank should
            anticipate the client's needs in relation to the
            setting up of a well-staffed project management unit,
            appropriate internal control systems, and developing terms
            of reference and procedures to monitor the performance of
            consultants and contractors.
